soap_summary:
## SUBJECTIVE
- A sixteen-year-old girl presented with discomfort in the neck and lower back, alongside restriction of body movements [CN_155216_0]. She developed pain and discomfort in her neck within the second week of starting olanzapine 5mg daily, associated with a sustained abnormal neck contraction pulling her head to the right [CN_155216_3]. She had a history of bipolar affective disorder diagnosed at age 11, previously managed with olanzapine [CF_155216_3].

## OBJECTIVE
- She was unable to maintain an erect posture and would fall to either side while standing [CN_155216_0]. The neck contraction caused a sideways bending of the lumbar region [CN_155216_0]. She had been experiencing these difficulties for four months since starting olanzapine [CN_155216_2].  She had previously been treated with trihexyphenidyl 4mg daily for upper limb rigidity [CN_155216_4]. [CS_155216_45]

## ASSESSMENT
- The patient presents with dystonia, likely related to olanzapine use [CF_155216_3, CF_155216_4]. The sustained neck contraction suggests a possible segmental dystonia or multifocal involvement [CF_155216_20]. [CS_155216_40]

## PLAN
- Olanzapine was reduced and stopped due to persistent symptoms [CF_155216_9].  Further investigation into the cause of the dystonia is warranted [Information needed: Further neurological evaluation and consideration of other medications]. [CS_155216_47]

The pain and discomfort in the back and neck have also reduced.
